intro: Dalechampia bernieri var. denisiana, commonly known as the Mexican beggar-ticks, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is characterized by its hairy, branched stems and small, clustered flowers. The leaves are alternate, ovate to lanceolate, and often have a rough texture. It produces capsule fruits that contain numerous tiny seeds, which are dispersed by wind. This plant is often found in dry, disturbed habitats such as roadsides and open woodlands.
